channel.title: NYT > Top Stories

item.title: The Hunt to Arm Ukraine Leads to Difficult Choices for Some Nations
item.description: The U.S. and NATO are scouring the world for new sources of old weapons to send to Ukraine. But it risks as much peril for some nations as it does promise for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with a Soviet-style assault rifle in Irpin in March. Ukrainian officials say their stockpiles of Soviet-style weapons, which many soldiers were trained to use, are running dangerously low.

item.title: Biden: Putin ‘Totally Miscalculated’ on Reaction to Ukraine Invasion
item.description: In an interview with CNN, Mr. Biden said he had “no intention" of talking to the Russian leader at a meeting next month, but would consider discussions about freeing Brittney Griner.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden at the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Los Angeles Confronts Racial Divide Anew After Leak of Racist Comments
item.description: Scores of residents demanded that three City Council members resign — as did President Biden — over a secretly recorded conversation that involved racist insults and slurs.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Sarah Reingewirtz/The Orange County Register, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mike Bonin, a member of the Los Angeles City Council, shed tears on Tuesday as he spoke about the racist comments directed toward his son.

item.title: Angela Lansbury, TV’s Favorite Sleuth on ‘Murder She Wrote,’ Dies at 96
item.description: She was a Hollywood and Broadway sensation, but she captured the biggest audience of her career as the TV sleuth Jessica Fletcher.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Lewis
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

item.title: A Streaming Guide to Angela Lansbury’s TV and Movie Roles
item.description: From appearances in films as varied as “The Manchurian Candidate” to “Beauty and the Beast” to her long run on “Murder, She Wrote” on television, she entertained for decades.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias

item.title: Christina Bobb, a Trump Lawyer, Is Under Justice Dept. Scrutiny
item.description: Christina Bobb is a former Marine and a fervent believer that the 2020 election was stolen from Donald J. Trump. She went to work for him and quickly found herself enmeshed in an obstruction investigation.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Megan Mendoza/The Republic, via USA Today Network
item.media:description: Christina Bobb, a former One America News Network anchor, was a late addition to former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team. She is now at the heart of the Justice Department’s criminal investigation into his handling of White House documents.

item.title: Biden Administration Considers Humanitarian Parole Program for Venezuelans
item.description: The program, an effort to deal with a surge in migrants, would be similar to one offered to Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: More than 150,000 Venezuelans have been apprehended at the southwestern U.S. border between October 2021 and the end of August.

item.title: For Venezuelan Migrants in South Florida, ‘Vision of a Certain Life’ Meets Reality
item.description: Doral, Fla., nicknamed “Doralzuela,” has become a destination for the many people fleeing a troubled country. There, they find support, and, ideally, a new home.
item.dc:creator: Peter Kujawinski and Erin Kirkland for The New York Times
item.media:credit: Erin Kirkland for The New York Times

item.title: For Zeldin, a Shooting Hits Close to Home and to His Campaign Theme
item.description: The shooting of two teenagers directly outside his Long Island home has given Mr. Zeldin an opportunity to push his tough-on-crime message within a personal frame.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: The shooting outside the home of Representative Lee Zeldin is being investigated as a possible gang-related incident.

item.title: NASA DART Mission Successfully Smashes Asteroid Into New Path
item.description: The DART mission proved more successful than expected in adjusting the trajectory of Dimorphos, suggesting that a deadly space rock could be deflected in the future.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles
item.media:credit: NASA/ESA/STScI/Hubble
item.media:description: An image captured by NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope on Oct. 8 showed a tail of debris blasted from the surface of Dimorphos 285 hours after the collision with the DART spacecraft.

item.title: Florida Jury Prepares to Decide Parkland Gunman’s Punishment
item.description: The jury will decide if the gunman who killed 17 people at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in 2018 gets sentenced to death or to life in prison.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Amy Beth Bennett
item.media:description: Melisa McNeill, a public defender, asked jurors to sentence Nikolas Cruz to life in prison during closing statements at the Broward County Courthouse in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Tuesday.

item.title: If You Want These Birkenstocks, You May Have to Pay Up
item.description: The classic “Boston” style has become a rare commodity and nearly impossible to find in stores. Resellers are having a field day.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher
item.media:credit: Jeremy Moeller/Getty Images
item.media:description: The rising popularity of the Birkenstock Boston clog on TikTok, particularly in the coveted taupe suede, has made it hard to find.

item.title: What Teenagers’ Mental Health Can Tell Us About America
item.description: Adolescents live at the fault lines of a culture, exposing our weak spots.
item.dc:creator: Jamieson Webster
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chantal Jahchan. Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: With Attacks, Russia’s Putin Is Trying to Terrorize Ukrainians
item.description: We are not back to the start of the war.
item.dc:creator: Margo Gontar
item.media:credit: Gleb Garanich/Reuters

item.title: A Cruel Death in Hebron
item.description: National liberation for Palestine means nothing without individual liberties for Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Oded Balilty/Associated Press

item.title: Kanye Shows Where the Right’s Troll Politics Lead
item.description: Why conservatives can’t condemn his antisemitism.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press

item.title: Why Do People Think Going to Therapy Makes You a Good Person?
item.description: The recent focus on therapy as a cure-all overlooks that there are other ways to heal.
item.dc:creator: Mychal Denzel Smith
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tyler Comrie; photograph by Getty Images/iStockphoto

item.title: A Nobel Prize for the Economics of Panic
item.description: The prize recognized important work explaining when and why financial markets implode.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by vanbeets and Bettmann via Getty Images

item.title: How Facebook Triggers My Bipolar Disorder
item.description: Social media didn’t cause my mental illness, but it exacerbated it. Now I have found a way to quiet the noise.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Eisler Vance
item.media:credit: Tommy Kha for The New York Times

item.title: We Were Three
item.description: A story of lies, family, America and what Covid revealed, as well as what it destroyed. All three parts arrive on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Updike, Jenelle Pifer, Julie Snyder and Sophie Allison of Soccer Mommy
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Is Ron DeSantis as Strong a Potential Candidate as He Seems?
item.description: The Florida governor looks to be well positioned to head into a hypothetical presidential primary in 2024. But past Republican darlings rose just as fast — only to fall quickly.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: In polls, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida consistently rates as the second choice of Republican voters, behind former President Donald Trump but well ahead of any putative rivals.

item.title: Revisiting Baldwin vs. Buckley
item.description: Nicholas Buccola talks about “The Fire Is Upon Us,” and Lydia Millet discusses “The Children’s Bible.”
item.media:credit: From left: Dave Pickoff/Associated Press; Associated Press
item.media:description: The 1965 debate between James Baldwin and William F. Buckley Jr. at the Cambridge Union was a crucial battle in the fight over civil rights.

item.title: Hangover Anxiety: How a Night of Drinking Can Tank Your Mood
item.description: Consuming alcohol can mess with your emotions the next day by causing stress hormones to spike and sleep to be disrupted overnight.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Pablo Delcan

item.title: Justice Dept. Asks Supreme Court to Reject Trump Request in Documents Case
item.description: The department said the justices should let stand an appeals court’s decision excluding about 100 sensitive documents seized at Mar-a-Lago from a special master’s review.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Whether former President Donald J. Trump wins or loses this round, the Justice Department will be able to continue its review of the sensitive documents and the larger litigation will move forward.

item.title: Kellye SoRelle’s Journey From Lawyer for Oath Keepers to Defendant
item.description: The lawyer, Kellye SoRelle, has been charged with working with the far-right militia to disrupt the 2020 election. Now, her text messages — and testimony — could emerge as evidence at their trial.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
item.media:credit: House Select Committee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kellye SoRelle, who served as a lawyer for the Oath Keepers, in a video released by the House committee investigating the Capitol riot.

item.title: Supreme Court Wrestles With Case on Pigs, Cruelty and Commerce
item.description: A California law requiring that pork sold in the state come from humanely raised pigs posed questions about how far states can go in affecting conduct outside their borders.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale/Reuters
item.media:description: A California law forbids the sale of most pork in the state unless the pig it comes from was born to a sow that was housed with 24 square feet of space.

item.title: Adnan Syed’s Charges Are Dropped by Baltimore Prosecutors
item.description: Mr. Syed, whose case was featured in the hit podcast “Serial,” had been convicted in the death of a high school classmate and spent 23 years in prison before being released last month.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed, the subject of the podcast “Serial,” leaving Baltimore City Circuit Court last month after a judge overturned his murder conviction in September.

item.title: Flu Shot: What to Know About Side Effects, Protection and Timing
item.description: And everything else you’ve been wondering about this annual vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: New Study Strengthens the Link Between Exercise and Memory
item.description: Experts have long known that fitness is good for the brain. A recent paper connects different types of workouts with assorted improvements in memory.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: Does CBD Help With Insomnia?
item.description: The research is sparse, experts say, but there are some hints about how it could soothe you to sleep.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Gravel Biking is Getting Popular. Here’s How to Start.
item.description: A faster bicycle design with thicker tires is allowing cyclists to explore America’s 2.2 million miles of Here’s what you need to know about this new sport.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Singleton
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett for The New York Times

item.title: How Do You Manage Omicron BA.5 Symptoms, Including a Sore Throat?
item.description: The longtime symptom of Covid is becoming more common, and sometimes more severe, with the dominant BA.5 subvariant.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: In Sussex, a Floral Designer Finds New Life in an Untamed Garden
item.description: After reluctantly moving into a tumbledown 17th-century English cottage, Milli Proust has created a gorgeously unruly and varied source for her craft.
item.dc:creator: Carolyn Asome and David Fernández

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
